metadata.metaValue: Here we create a plane of points then use their positions to generate colors
The time node provides time and frame information.
This fCurve  provides the repeating motion of the points by having it's pre- and post-evaluation set to "cycling", causing an oscillating animation.
We use the colors generated in the previous compound as an emissive shader on the points, enabling us to render then as "glowing"

We use the colors generated by the ***sample_points_by_radius*** compound to color our ground plane.  These are the colors in a radius of the point object.  Try changing settings on the ***sample_points_by_radius*** compound to see different results.
The two objects, now colored, are output for display and rendering in Arnold.
Please feel free to replace with your own geo.

# ***sample_point_by_radius***

For every *position* input it will search within a *radius* for points in the `geometry` and return a *weighted average* of the property by the distance to the samples.

For example, if a position samples 4 points in a given radius then it will average the property at those 4 points based on the distance to those points.
This example demonstrates weighted sampling between points and a plane
The incoming y_position is converted to a vector to use as the position of the plane.  This provides the animation.
This is the plane that will be providing our colored points
The point information will provide both the position of our points and the color.
Because the position can be both positive and negative, we resample the array into a range of 0-1 in all channels to provide a color.
